awd_titl_txt: CSR: Medium: Collaborative Research: Wizard: Exploiting Disk Performance Signatures for Cost-Effective Management of Large-Scale Storage Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
The tremendous advances in low-cost, high-capacity magnetic hard disk drives, flash-based solid state drives and non-volatile memory have been among the key factors supporting big data applications and various computing-storage services that the modern society deeply relies on. However, storage drives are reported to be the most commonly replaced hardware components because of failures. This causes service downtime and even data loss, costing enterprises multi-trillion dollars per year. Existing disk failure management approaches are mostly reactive and incur high overheads; they do not provide a cost-effective solution to managing large-scale production storage systems. The goal of this project is to achieve a deep understanding of the reliability of the real-world storage systems, and to develop a cost-effective data and storage resource management system for reliability enhancement.
 
The investigators' approach to building reliable, large-scale storage systems is carefully designed to support storage health monitoring, modeling, prediction and proactive recovery in a systematic fashion. In particular, they first categorize and model storage failures to derive disk performance signatures and explore disk performance signatures to forecast occurrences of disk failures. They then characterize I/O workload dependency in disk performance degradation and integrate the performance signatures of heterogeneous disk devices to effectively reconfigure and manage storage resources. Furthermore, the project will provide easy-to-use APIs for storage users and developers to employ the developed tools and techniques for proactive data rescue and preventive disk reliability enhancement. Finally, the project provides excellent opportunities for training graduate students, especially minority and female students, and for developing new curriculum materials on reliable storage systems.

por.por_cntn:
This project has characterized different types of disk failures and explored machine learning technologies to discover disk failure types, derive degradation signatures, predict failures, and protect data. Specially, the outcomes of this project are as follows.

A disk failure categorization mechanism has been developed. Groups of disk failures with different manifestations have been identified and their types have been further determined. We have also developed the disk performance degradation modeling method. The degradation processes are accurately identified, and disk performance signatures are derived.

A disk degradation monitoring mechanism that can determine the degradation status for disk health state has been developed. We have developed a differentiated disk failure prediction approach to predict occurrence time of future disk failures based on disks’ degradation history and the performance signatures. We have designed the self-evolvement mechanism to keep disk failure predictors updated.

A correlation model between applications, I/O behaviors, and disk performance and failures has been derived. It can predict the performance degradation of disks under various types of applications. We have characterized the I/O workloads patterns for various big data and machine learning applications, and further modeled the influence of application I/O accesses and drives’ ambient temperature on drives’ performance and reliability.

Heterogeneous (such as hard disk drives and solid-state drives) disk characteristic models have been built. They characterize the unique reliability properties of diverse storage devices. Data recovery strategies have been designed and evaluated. They use the performance degradation signatures and leverage degradation monitoring and failure prediction to determine cost-effective data recovery operations.

The outcomes of this research advance the understanding of failure modes and performance degradation dynamics of heterogeneous disk devices in storage systems, and enable new storage management tools and applications that can unleash the capabilities of modern large-scale, heterogeneous storage systems.

4 PhD students (1 female), 3 master’s students (2 female), and 4 REU students (1 female, 1 African American, and 1 Hispanic) have participated in the project. This project has also produced 3 journal articles and 32 conference papers published in peer-reviewed international journals and conferences. Data sets and technical papers have been made publicly available. The research results have been integrated into 6 courses taught at the University of North Texas, such as Systems Programming, Computer Architecture, Operating Systems Design, Real-Time Operating Systems, and Advanced Distributed Computing.
